block.p: Putin Suggests New Way To Foil Missile Attacks President Vladimir Putin of Russia, seeking to recast a security debate just before his summit meeting with President Clinton, has suggested an alternative to the proposed American system for defending against missile attacks by nations like North Korea. Mr. Putin hinted that the United States and Russia could collaborate on new ways to shoot down missiles soon after they were launched, rather than in space.

Putin Suggests New Way To Foil Missile Attacks President Vladimir Putin of Russia, seeking to recast a security debate just before his summit meeting with President Clinton, has suggested an alternative to the proposed American system for defending against missile attacks by nations like North Korea. Mr. Putin hinted that the United States and Russia could collaborate on new ways to shoot down missiles soon after they were launched, rather than in space.
Integrating Russia Into Europe President Clinton urged America's European allies to invite Russia into their military and political unions or risk destroying the vision of an undivided Continent.
Moscow Challenged on Atrocity Human Rights Watch called on the Russian government to seek out and try the servicemen who went on a rampage near Grozny on Feb. 5, killing at least 60 civilians.

No Investigation of NATO The United Nations' chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, said there was no basis for an investigation into whether NATO committed war crimes during the bombing of Yugoslavia last year.

Nazi Slave Labor Deal Snagged An agreement in which German industry and the government agreed to pay Holocaust survivors nearly $5 billion became entangled in disagreements with the United States over protecting the companies from future lawsuits.

Arrest in 1978 Italian Killing The French police arrested Alvaro Loiacono, a former member of the Italian Red Brigades, in the killing of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro of Italy in 1978. Mr. Moro was kidnapped before he was killed in the group's most notorious attack.

Cuba Open to Claims Talks Havana is prepared to hold talks with American companies that had property seized when Fidel Castro came to power 40 years ago, a United States Chamber of Commerce official said after a trip to Cuba.
Baker to Monitor Mexico Vote Former Secretary of State James Baker will lead a 35-member delegation to observe the July 2 presidential election, the International Republican Institute said.

H.M.O.'s Seen to Curtail Participation in Medicare More H.M.O.'s will soon pull out of Medicare or curtail their participation for financial reasons, disrupting insurance coverage for hundreds of thousands of elderly people, according to federal officials, independent experts and managed-care executives. Cigna said it would end coverage for 104,000 Medicare beneficiaries in 11 states: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Maryland, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia. Aetna, with 676,000 Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in its H.M.O., said it would pull out of some markets.

F.A.A. Warns Airline The F.A.A. threatened to shut down major maintenance overhauls at Alaska Airlines, which would ground the airline within months. The agency, its attention drawn to the airline by a fatal crash last January and a federal grand jury investigation, said the carrier had trouble keeping track of required maintenance and that managers had not noticed the problem.

Tension Over Campaign Inquiry Quarrels between the Justice Department and the F.B.I. over appointment of an independent campaign finance investigator had a ''devastating impact'' on relations among investigators, officials acknowledged in a report by the General Accounting Office.

Gore on Absent Fathers Vice President Al Gore called for measures to encourage absent fathers, whom he called ''the No. 1 cause of child poverty in America,'' to pay child support. He also urged government policies that would ''lift up the institution of marriage.''

Conviction in O'Hair Case A federal jury in Austin, Tex., convicted Gary Paul Karr on several charges relating to the disappearance of the atheist Madalyn Murray O'Hair, her son and her granddaughter, but acquitted Mr. Karr, 52, of conspiracy to commit kidnapping.

Satellite Heading for Ocean NASA engineers prepared for the fiery plunge into the Pacific this weekend of the 17-ton Compton Gamma Ray Observatory. Only two of its three stabilizing gyroscopes have been functioning since December, and NASA feared the consequences of its losing another gyroscope and plunging to earth on its own.

State Environment Agency Approves New Power Plant The Pataki administration gave final environmental approval to build the nation's largest power plant in the Hudson River town of Athens, 30 miles south of Albany. The $500 million natural-gas-fired plant was proposed by Pacific Gas & Electric.

Life After the Senate Race Two weeks after he dropped out of the Senate race for health reasons and saying he wanted to be a better person and mayor, Mayor Giuliani has begun making tentative overtures to some former enemies.

Lazio Seeks Jewish Support Representative Rick A. Lazio met in Manhattan with Jewish leaders, seeking support in his Senate campaign from a key constituency that usually favors Democrats but may be up for grabs this year.

Doctors' Troubled Histories Two radiologists whose licenses were suspended by the state after accusations that they had administered faulty mammograms have a history of problems in their practices, according to records and interviews with former associates.

A Final Flurry of Spending Jon S. Corzine, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Senate in New Jersey, is expected to spend up to $2 million next week to try to get supporters to the polls, a sum approaching the get-out-the-vote budget for many presidential contests.
Knicks' Season Ends The Indiana Pacers defeated the Knicks, 93-80, in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.
The Portland Trail Blazers beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 103-93, tying the Western Conference finals at 3-3.
Reunited in Pursuit of a Trophy The New York Yacht Club will field a challenge to the next Kiwi defense of the America's Cup, in 2002-3, under the command of the four-time cup winner, Dennis Conner.

Sign of a Slowdown The Labor Department said the nation's private employers, instead of hiring, shed 116,000 jobs in May. It was the largest drop in more than eight years and the first since the economy began to soar in the mid-1990's. The unemployment rate edged up to 4.1 percent from 3.9 percent. Wage increases eased, reducing concerns about inflation. Investors pushed stocks up across the board in the belief that the evidence would discourage or limit further interest rate increases by the Fed.

The Nasdaq soared 6.44 percent, up 230.88 points, to 3,813.38, ending its best week ever. The Dow rose 142.56 points, or 1.34 percent, to 10,794.76, and the S.& P. 500 jumped 28.45 points, or 1.96 percent, to 1,477.26.

Airline Merger Buzz Speculation has intensified that the next acquisition target in the airline industry is Northwest, and there have already been talks between Northwest and AMR, the parent of American, executives confirmed.

Leftists Control Pension Fund A radical-left coalition now controls all three elected seats on the six-member board of Brazil's largest and most influential pension fund, known as Previ, with $17.5 billion.
Oprah Editor Resigns The editor of O: The Oprah Magazine, Ellen Kunes, is resigning for personal reasons after just one issue went on sale.
Editorials: Mr. Clinton's weekend in Moscow; measuring the progress of women; public necessities; a mambo king bows out. Columns: Frank Rich, Anthony Lewis.
